issues.title: Sorting out the options for the parent on receipt of a NOTIFY(CDS)
issues.author: johanix
issues.body:
This is my view:

1. Schedule immediate check. Reset "refresh" to max value (i.e. in practice, put this child at the end of the queue, but don't put it on a separate slower queue.
2. Schedule immediate check. Put child of a slow-burner queue used for children known to issue NOTIFY(CDS).
3. Ignore.

Option one improves service but doesn't reduce cost. Option two improves service and reduces cost (apart from implementation complexity). Option three is a no-op.

Is this sthe same as your view, or am I missing some important detail in the current text?

comments.author: peterthomassen
comments.body:
I think 1&2 are very similar, and don't need to be spelled out separately. I merged 1&2 together, and now the sentence just says:
```
     The parent MAY reset the scanning timer for children for which
     NOTIFY(CDS) is received, or reduce the periodic scanning frequency
     accordingly (e.g. to every two weeks).
```

IMO the details of that are local policy, so don't need to go into the document. (Perhaps operators will come up with yet different algorithms for handling children known to support NOTIFY(CDS), so our enumeration may not be comprehensive anyway.)

issues.title: Should we add a bit of document complexity by going into *responses* to NOTIFY(*)?
issues.author: johanix
issues.body:
Most people are more or less unaware that NOTIFY is a message with a response. 

As the aim is to get away from as much brute-force scanning as possible (i.e. try to do one better than RFC 1996 did for NOTIFY(SOA) to replace the refresh counter) I think it would be helpful to point out that there are responses and the response may be used as a signalling mechanism. I.e.:

child sends NOTIFY(CDS). Parent may respond with:

NOERROR: all good, we support NOTIFY(CDS) and your request will be dealt with shortly

REFUSED: we don't care about NOTIFY(CDS) (in spite of having a notification address published). We'll just continue to do inefficient scanning.

Any other alternative?

comments.author: johanix
comments.body: I argue to leave it out from the first draft. But I think for the long term goal it may be the thing that tilts the balance.

comments.author: peterthomassen
comments.body: Ack (leave out for now, discuss later)

issues.title: Add RRSIG(Question) to Additional section
issues.author: brian-peter-dickson
issues.body:
It would be ideal to include any/all RRSIGs along with the record used for the Notify.
This would prevent garbage submissions (attacks), at least in theory.
Since the Question section currently can only have one RR, the obvious placement would be the Additional section.

A recipient could do whatever level of sanity checks, verifications, and validations it desire, possibly sequentially to limit the ability of anyone to induce the requester to do work.

E.g. first, check for the presence of RRSIGs (reject any Notifies without one). Then check that the Key Tag is a match for one of the DNSKEYs with SEP set. Then check against existing records (ignore Notifies where the record in the Question is not "new"). Then actually do signature verification.

comments.author: johanix
comments.body:
The Question section is not limited to only have one RR. The problem has traditionally been how to interpret a DNS message with "multiple queries". In this case (sending Notifies) I think the interpretation is at least manageable. 

As a case in point, I have code that sends both a Notify(CDS) and a Notify(CSYNC) in the same message to my test service. This has a rather obvious interpretation and works perfectly.

Regarding attaching the RRSIGs to, eg. the Notify(CDS) I don't see how that would solve the problem with garbage Notifications as both the RR and the RRSIG(RR) are publically available. The only thing this would do is to make it trivially more complicated to construct the garbage. 

To my mind the way to deal with the risk of garbage Notifications is the same as for normal Notifies (i.e. Notify(SOA)): ensure that receipt of a Notify does not in any way change the logic for what is required for the zone to be updated. In the Notify(SOA) case this is well known (secondary queries for the SOA, only a bit earlier than otherwise, and makes a decision). In the Notify(CDS) or Notify(CSYNC) cases I believe in similar logic: do the same scan as would otherwise happen later and make the same decision as would otherwise still have happened.

Assuming that the way to deal with garbage notifications becomes, I hope, mostly a matter of guarding the service with some sort of reasonable rate-limiting defence.

comments.author: peterthomassen
comments.body: I'm going to push a commit to address this concern; the changes will be part of the next revision. As the document has been adopted, I'm closing this here; please re-raise on the DNSOP list if needed.

issues.title: Destination for gTLDs?
issues.author: brian-peter-dickson
issues.body:
Maybe add a section to discuss the open question of how to direct Notify messages when the TLD is using the RRR model.
In RRR, the Registrant is not allowed to communicate directly with the Registry.
In other words, the Registrant would need to send the Notify to the Registrar, presumably on some pre-agreed-upon destination IP.

That IP may need to be established on a per-domain basis (not necessarily unique, but also not globally identical for all domains at a given Registrar).
The agreement might be done via publishing in DNS, but that does come with some risk for discovery and DOS/abuse.

Thinking out loud, given that the Registrant operates a DNSSEC signed zone and publishes a public key while possessing a private key, the Registrar could theoretically encrypt the information using the Registrant's public key, which would restrict the ability to decrypt the information to only the Registrant.
OTOH, that might not scale very well, so it's just a placeholder idea for now.
ACLs might work, but similarly have scaling issues.

Some kind of pub/sub thing to allow Registrants to publish information about their Notifier systems, that the Registrar could discover (at scale) might be a method. The Registrant would use some well-known publication point (underscore name), and sign the record (preventing forgery).

Registrar would discover the publication point via polling, and then acknowledge at its own publication point, allowing the Registrant to know it is okay to use the address (however that address is learned.)

comments.author: johanix
comments.body:
HI Brian,

I agree that this is something that warrants careful thought. However, my feeling is that the discussion must happen in the working group. I.e. while agreeing with you I think we should defer this until the document has been adopted (assuming it will be).

Johan Stenstam

comments.body:

issues.title: Consider impact of encrypted transports on amplification attacks
issues.author: bemasc
issues.body:
If a single UDP NOTIFY packet can cause the parent and child servers to establish an encrypted connection, this may represent a form of amplification: the resources consumed by the victim are much larger than the resources expended by the attacker.

Also, QUIC Initials are large, and may create a risk of classical amplification.

comments.author: peterthomassen
comments.body: Thanks for your feedback. - Do you think the problem could be addressed by mandating TCP?

comments.author: johanix
comments.body:
While I agree with this my immediate response is that the standard way of dealing with amplification attacks is RRL and in this case RRL ought to work extremely well. While it can be argued that a single source has a need to send a certain volume of queries, sometimes even for the same data, this cannot be said for these notifications. It is clearly enough to accept one notification per child zone and suitable time unit.

So I think that there exists standard measures to deal with this issue.

comments.author: bemasc
comments.body:
> Do you think the problem could be addressed by mandating TCP?

I wouldn't mandate TCP when we also have UDP+COOKIE, TLS, QUIC, etc.  That aside, I think a rate limit by source IP would also be required.  (Even then, it's not clear what to say about IPv6, or attackers who control large IPv4 blocks.)

> It is clearly enough to accept one notification per child zone and suitable time unit.

Is it?  What about an attacker who deliberately exhausts the child zone's quota to prevent rapid key rotation after a compromise?  What about an attacker who sends one NOTIFY for each child zone in order to attack a large registry?

comments.author: peterthomassen
comments.body: I'm going to push a commit to address this concern; the changes will be part of the next revision. As the document has been adopted, I'm closing this here; please re-raise on the DNSOP list if needed.

issues.title: Support for NOTIFY(SOA)
issues.author: kpfleming
issues.body:
Recently I'd been considering writing up something which would allow for *dynamic* registration of NOTIFY(SOA) targets... and then this draft came along and addressed most of what I was going to propose :-)

In various operational scenarios the list of secondary servers, and other servers who are interested in SOA RR changes, is not fixed, but changes as servers are brought online and offline. In my experience (primarily with PowerDNS), this requires making configuration changes at the primary server to make it aware of the current list of NOTIFY(SOA) targets. In PowerDNS this information is stored in 'zone metadata' (outside of the zone contents), but this draft provides a way for that metadata to be both standardized and stored within the zone contents.

The ability to host a NOTIFY(SOA) record for each target, combined with the ability for those targets to use TSIG-authenticated UPDATE to add (or remove) their own NOTIFY(SOA) records, would provide a nice solution to this problem.

comments.author: peterthomassen
comments.body: Aren't catalog zones (RFC 9432) the solution for that? (You'd be doing your DDNS update on the catalog zone for the relevant secondary.)

comments.author: kpfleming
comments.body:
In my experience so far, catalog zones handle the *what* for zone replication, but not the *when*.

If it helps, here's the scenario:

Hidden primary authoritative server P has a list of zones.

Some of those zones have public secondaries (A, B,  and C) which are listed in the NS RRsets of the relevant zones. P uses those lists to send NOTIFY(SOA) to A, B and C when appropriate.

There are additional non-public secondaries D and E, which are not listed in the NS RRsets of any of the zones. In addition there are recursive resolvers F and G which also desire to receive NOTIFY(SOA) from P when the zone contents are changed.

Today P must have D, E, F, and G all recorded in non-zone-content metadata in order to deliver NOTIFY(SOA) messages to them.

I'd like to have a mechanism for D, E, F and G to be able to indicate to P their details in order to receive the relevant NOTIFY(SOA) messages; if this 'generalized notify' mechanism was available, those systems could inject NOTIFY RRs into the necessary zones to be added to the NOTIFY(SOA) lists. For this to be a fully dynamic mechanism, there would also need to be some method for those records to expire automatically.

comments.author: jrlevine
comments.body:
> I'd like to have a mechanism for D, E, F and G to be able to indicate to P their details in order to receive the relevant NOTIFY(SOA) messages; 

I wouldn't want to let random hosts ask for notifies. It's none of their business, and it's a vector for abuse if a hostile party can fake someone else's IP (still pretty easy within many networks.) You need authentication, but by the time you figure out how to distribute the keys, just skip the keys and do the notifies to the places you would have sent the keys.

On the other hand, catalog zones are designed to be extensible and it would be easy to put notify info into them. e.g.:

```
; where to send notifies, defaults to secondaries
; explicit secondaries
notifyto.ext.<unique>.zones.$CATZ  0 IN PTR A
notifyto.ext.<unique>.zones.$CATZ  0 IN PTR B
notifyto.ext.<unique>.zones.$CATZ  0 IN PTR C
; kibitzers
notifyto.ext.<unique>.zones.$CATZ  0 IN PTR D
notifyto.ext.<unique>.zones.$CATZ  0 IN PTR E
notifyto.ext.<unique>.zones.$CATZ  0 IN PTR F
notifyto.ext.<unique>.zones.$CATZ  0 IN PTR G

; hidden primary for notify, defaults to SOA primary
notifyfrom.ext.<unique>.zones.$CATZ  0 IN PTR P
```

D, E, F, G have to know to AXFR the catalog zone to know where the primary is and what zones they're kibitzing, but that's a one time thing. Everything else can be automated.

This is the same reason I am not crazy about section 4.1 where to send the notifies. It doesn't handle hidden primaries in the child zone, and it scales poorly in TLDs where there may be millions of zones.

comments.author: kpfleming
comments.body:
> I wouldn't want to let random hosts ask for notifies. It's none of their business, and it's a vector for abuse if a hostile party can fake someone else's IP (still pretty easy within many networks.) You need authentication, but by the time you figure out how to distribute the keys, just skip the keys and do the notifies to the places you would have sent the keys.

I disagree there; distributing a key to a NOTIFY(SOA) consumer is a significantly different operation from modifying the configuration of the primary auth server. In my case it's done by Ansible playbooks/roles, but others will use a variety of configuration management tools.

I'd certainly be happy to use a mechanism relying on catalog zones for this; after all, the list of NOTIFY(SOA) receivers is itself a catalog :-)

comments.author: jrlevine
comments.body:
> I'd certainly be happy to use a mechanism relying on catalog zones for this; after all, the list of NOTIFY(SOA) receivers is itself a catalog :-)

How about writing up a draft that does that, something like what was in my example?

issues.title: Avoid overloading the term "NOTIFY"
issues.author: peterthomassen
issues.body:
The draft currently says:

```
In the text below there are two different uses of the term
"NOTIFY". One refers to the NOTIFY message, sent from a DNSSEC signer
or name server to a notification target (for subsequent
processing). We refer to this message as NOTIFY(RRtype) where the
RRtype indicates the type of NOTIFY message (CDS or CSYNC).

The second is a proposed new DNS record type, with the suggested
mnemonic "NOTIFY". This record is used to publish the location of the
notification target. We refer to this as the "NOTIFY record".
```

I found myself repeatedly confused by NOTIFY sometimes denoting the record in the parent, and sometimes denoting the message sent by the child.

There may be a risk of confusing other people as well. - Can we think of resolving this ambiguity? (As the message is already called NOTIFY by RFC 1996, we'd have to rename the record type.)

comments.author: jrlevine
comments.body: Good point, the RRTYPE is not the notification but the end point. I suppose YFITON would be too clever.

comments.body: fixed in #22

issues.title: Error reporting
issues.author: peterthomassen
issues.body:
I was thinking about ways for the NOTIFY receiver (i.e., parent) to communicate an error condition to the DNS operator.

Perhaps good ideas:
- [ ] Allow the DNS operator to add a record in the NOTIFY message, indicating an error reporting channel (e.g. SRV record with some host/port, or a TXT record with an email address, or something different. It would need to be standardized; but the basic idea probably is clear.)
- [ ] Send an EDNS0 Report-Channel option in the NOTIFY message (RFC 9567). The parent then can send a reporting query to the DNS operator's monitoring agent later if needed.

In both cases, to prevent reflection attacks, the report target's last labels could be required to be one of the NS hostnames (or something like that).

Probably bad ideas:
- [ ] Act immediately and delay the NOTIFY response until either success or an error condition occurred, and communicate the result in the response. The problem is that this creates pressure on the receiver to come to a conclusion within seconds, which may not be acceptable given that DS provisioning may take longer (including bootstrapping fetches, acceptance checks etc.). Related: #11 
- [ ] Allow the DNS operator to publish a reporting endpoint under their nameserver, e.g. `_notify-report.$child._signal.ns1.provider.net`, or similar (need not be child-specific). The problem here is that there may be multiple NS by different operators, and it's not clear which of the published endpoints is the one related to the NOTIFY that was sent.

comments.author: peterthomassen
comments.body: Some indicated that "EDNS0 Report-Channel option in the NOTIFY message (RFC 9567)" (option 2 above) is preferable, as it's already standardized.
